results.title: Haig: the unknown soldier
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
Scottish field Marshall Sir Douglas Haig is infamous for being known as the man responsible for sending 723,000 British soldiers to their deaths - carnage on an unheard of scale. Inarticulate and stubborn, Haig was accused of being callous and incompetent, the “Butcher of the Somme,” the donkey in charge of the British army of lions. Lampooned and caricatured in the media - print then, television now (BlackAdder). Research by military historians into the performance of the British Army in World War 1 queries the myth of Haig as a buffoon in his position as British Commander in Chief on the Western Front, a post he assumed in December 1915. The program postulates that casualties were high given that it was a war of industrial powers and all that this entailed on a military scale. Provides brief biographical information, readings from Haig’s diary, interviews with historians and veterans and archival footage.

group_siblings.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, Lionheart TV International and BBC

results.title: Haida carver
results.brief_description: A young Haida Indian artist shapes miniature totems from argillite, a stone-like jet. Shows the island where he finds the stone, and how he carves it in the manner of his grandfather who taught him the craft. His grandmother shows delight as she polishes each new piece to a gbeautiful black gloss. Weathered monuments stand among the tall firs on Canada’s Pacific coast, where the whittlers used to carve the giant totems.

results.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The third program in the “Roman’s in Britain” series which discusses the history of one of the most famous landmarks of Roman Britain, Hadrian’s Wall. Through interviews with historians, archaeologists and museum curators and a discussion of artifacts and construction patterns present at the site, this episode explores the various theories about who built the wall, its purpose for the Roman Empire, and the impact it had on early Britain. A commentary on the gradual downfall of the Romans in Britain and their remaining legacy in a variety of forms in the country concludes the program.

results.title: Habitat UK 76
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Michael Birkett and Anthony Wilkinson
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of redevelopment of cities. Emphasises that circumstances forever change and uses Birmingham as an example that single, large-scale comprehensive approaches to planning may not be the best approach.

results.title: Habitat
results.creator_credit: United Nations Films and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Human habitat is any place where humans live. In the past most habitats were rural and posed relatively simple problems. At the moment, the human race is posing entirely new, and often complex problems. This film describes some of these problems and suggests some solutions

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: The wheely bird
results.brief_description: Jimmy, his magic flute Freddy and best friend H.R. Pufnstuf have to battle the evil Witchiepoo. In this episode, Jimmy and Pufnstuf use a bird-shaped “Trojan Horse” as a trick in order to enter Witchiepoo’s castle to recover the stolen Golden Flute Freddie.

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: the magic path
results.brief_description: On a walk through the forest, Jimmy and his magic flute Freddy are lured away by Witchiepoo to Living Island. They remain trapped when Witchiepoo makes the Magic Path disappear and Jimmy must rely on the resources and loyalty of his best friend H.R. Pufnstuf to get him out of trouble.

results.title: H.M.S. Pinafore
results.brief_description: Gilbert and Sullivan’s rollicking tale of love upon the high seas. Stars Peter Marshall as Captain Corcoran and Frankie Howard as Sir Joseph Porter. With the London Symphony Orchestra and the Ambrosian Opera Chorus. Rated: G
